name: Trini-Chinese Chicken
description: Chinese-style chicken is a dish you can find all over Trinidad and within the diaspora that has followed the nation’s emergence from British rule. The skin is fried into a lacquered mahogany. The meat beneath it tastes of five-spice, ginger and soy and is generally accompanied by a hum of oyster sauce mixed with the zing of the pickled Scotch-bonnet-pepper sauce that is seemingly omnipresent on the island’s tables.
keywords: chicken, chinese five-spice powder, soy sauce, main course
recipeIngredient: 8 to 10 chicken thighs, legs and wings,about 2 1/2 to 3 pounds total
1/2 cup neutral oil, like canola or grapeseed
1 to 3 tablespoons Scotch-bonnet-peppersauce, ideally Matouk’s Soca, to taste

recipeInstructions.text:
In a large, nonreactive bowl, toss the
chicken with five-spice powder, then with
the juice of 2 of the limes, the soy sauce
and the ginger. Cover and marinate in the
refrigerator for at least 30 minutes and
up to 6 hours.

Heat oils in a large skillet over medium-high
heat. There should be at least
1/4 inch of oil in the pan. When the oil is
hot, remove chicken from marinade,
allowing excess marinade to drip back
into the bowl, and fry, in batches if
necessary to not crowd the pan, turning
the pieces frequently, until well browned
and cooked through, 15 to 20 minutes.

Meanwhile, make the dipping sauce.
Combine oyster sauce, a tablespoon
of the Scotch-bonnet-pepper sauce and
the juice of the remaining lime and stir
to combine. Adjust seasonings with more
hot sauce, lime juice and freshly ground
black pepper to taste.

Garnish with scallions and serve with
white or fried rice, with a drizzle of the
sauce over each piece of chicken and the
remaining sauce on the side.
